seg.seg: all the way [up] to the Śuddhāvāsa- world of the gods, [all] splendid things are seen alive on the (Buddha-like) body. 2. Thereupon Bṛhaddyuti,

Darauf verehrte Bṛhaddyuti, der mit über die Maßen großer Freude nahe an den ehrwürdigen Buddha Śākyamuni herangekommen war, (mit) größter Hochachtung [und] Ehrerbietung, mit aneinandergelegten Händen die Füße des Śākyamuni, und dem unersättlich anzusehenden buddhaschaftlichen Körper die Rechte (zukehrend), spricht er zum Buddha: "Wenn, o Arhat, einer wie ich würdig wäre, (deinen) leuchtenden ... (Körper zu berühren), [so] möchte ich die Erlaubnis [dazu] erlangen, mit eigener Hand möchte ich den Buddha baden. Du, der du den [deinen] Wunsch erfüllenden [ihren] Wunsch gewährst, (erlaube es mir(?))."

Thereupon, Bṛhaddyuti, who, with joy beyond measure had come close to the venerable Buddha Śākyamuni, (with) the greatest respect [and] deference, with hands folded, venerated the feet of Śākyamuni, and (turning) [his] right (towards) the Buddha-like body, satelessly to be looked at, and says to the Buddha: “If, oh arhat, one like me was worthy (of touching your) bright ... (body), I would like to gain permission to bathe the Buddha with [my] own hand! You, who grants the wish[es] of those adhering to [your] wishes, (permit me(?) [to do so]).”

If [someone] like me, o arhat, were worthy of touching your dignified body, may I obtain the permission that I may wash the Buddha with my own hand! (cf 27)
touching your dignified body, may I obtain the permission that I may wash the Buddha with my own hand! You that are granting the wish of those who fulfil a wish,
(permit me to do so! 1. (Thereupon with a lovely) voice, Śākyamuni, the Buddha says: Do so, my son; bathe you the body of the Buddha yourself!
Tue so, [mein] Sohn, bade du selbst des Buddhas Körper!
Do so, [my] son, bathe you the Buddha's body yourself.
(When Bṛhaddyuti then,) the potter, having obtained the Buddha’s permission, and, full of joy, approaching the Buddha in a revering manner, he saw
(his hands)..., [which were,] due to working the clay, rough, hard, dry, covered in clay, cold and not fit to
touch the Buddha’s body. Immediately he recoiled with timidity and with tears in his eyes at the Buddha's

Sofort wich er [wtl. hob er sich] mit Scheu zurück [und] dachte, mit tränenden Augen auf den Körper des Buddha, des Meisters, blickend: "Aller Glanz, Adel, Zartheit [und] (Lieblichkeit) [ist] an dem Körper des Buddha, [aber] trocken, hart, rauh [und] kalt [sind] meine tonbearbeitenden Hände, schwerfällig geworden."

Immediately he recoiled shyly [and] thought, gazing with tear-filled eyes on the body of the Buddha, the Master: "All brilliance, nobility, tenderness [and] (grace) [is] on the body of the Buddha, [but] dry, hard, rough [and] cold are my clay-working hands, having become clumsy."
body he looked and thought: || In the Y.-tune: || All splendour, nobility, tenderness [and]
(pleasantness) [are] on the body of the Buddha; dry, hard, raw/rough [and] cold [are] my clay-working hands, [they are] impeded. The body of the Buddha, surpassing a heavenly lotus-leaf,
soft, gold-coloured, how could I miserable one touch it? Or don’t I touch it?
How could I miserable one touch it? Or don't I touch it? … What am I doing? (cf 29)

p.note: The translation is largely based on 27-28, and .

The leaf number on the margin has been lost, but a number 7(·) (most likely 77) is written inside the string hole of the verso side by a different hand. Since this leaf stands in a continuous series, it actually ought to have the leaf number 87. The combination of lost margin and deviating string-hole numbering starts in and continues until .
Siegling in his personal copy of p. 18corrects the original reading mā ne tsinām to mā te tsinām, with the question particle te rather than ne (cf. also 28 n.3 and 631).
